title: Financial Funds - Revised
headline: This course covers types of financial funds - such as open-ended, closed-end, mutual and hedge - clearly and concisely.
description: In this free online hedge funds course, you can develop your understanding of financial funds and economics. Terms like ‘hedge funds’, ‘open-ended funds’, and ‘mutual funds’ are regularly employed by fund managers and the financial media but few people truly understand what they mean. This course will give you a better understanding of these terms and their role in economics in a few short hours.

courseDescription:
An open-end mutual fund is a diversified portfolio of assets created by pooling investors’ money. This course will teach you how an open-end mutual fund provides an easy, low-cost way to pool money and purchase a diversified portfolio reflecting a specific investment objective. You will also look into a closed-end mutual fund, which is a portfolio of pooled assets that raises a fixed amount of capital through an initial public offering (IPO) and then lists shares for trade on a stock exchange.

Then study exchange traded funds (ETFs), a collection of securities that tracks an underlying index. You will learn that an EFT is a marketable security with an associated price for buying and selling. Be introduced to hedge funds where you will learn about their structures and fees. You will also study venture capital, which has high-risk/high-return opportunities, and private equity which is composed of funds and investors that directly invest in private companies.

Hedge funds are typically open-ended funds invested in a diverse range of assets. Open and close-ended funds are straight forward. The former is open to shareholders in terms of buying and selling of shares. The latter is closed and once you buy in you cannot leave unless you personally trade your share. By taking this course, you will gain a clear understanding of these types of funds and learn how fund managers make money through performance and commission.

Start Course Now

All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module learn more about mutual, open, closed and hedge funds. You will begin by learning about open-end mutual funds and closed-end mutual funds before moving onto exchange traded funds. You will learn about how each of these funds operate and the advantages of each type for the fund manager. After this, you will begin to look at Hedge Funds, Hedge Fund Strategies and the way that a Hedge Fund manager analyses the stock market in order to make the best decision for their fund.
topics: Hedge Funds, Venture Capital and Private Equity

modules.name: Module
topics: Hedge Fund Strategies - Long Short 2 Seeing How The Long-Short Portfolio Might Do in Different Market Conditions
Hedge Fund Strategies - 3 - Merger Arbitrage 1 Simple Case Of Merger Arbitrage When There Is An All Cash Acquisition

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • After completing this module, you will be able to:

    • Understand acronyms relating to financial funds.

    • Explain how open-end and closed-end mutual funds operate.

    • Calculate the Net Asset Value (NAV) per share.

    • Describe how Hedge Funds operate and the role that the SEC plays with hedge funds.

    • Explain why there is an element of secrecy to do with hedge funds.

    • Discuss the role of fund managers in different types of funds and the fees that they can earn in each.

    • Explain the dangers when something is 'too big to fail'.

    • Describe the differences between Venture Capital Funds and Private Equity.

• Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:

    • When a company is established, they must register with the SEC which stands for the Securities and Exchange Commission.
    • The money that goes to shareholders for choosing the best strategies for investment is known as AUM or Assets Under Management.
    • In a mutual fund, the fund manager solicits funds from the public to carry out business.
    • The NAV or Net Asset Value of a share is calculated by dividing the total NAV by the number of shares.
    • If a shareholder buys back a share this does not affect the NAV per share because while the Total NAV goes down so too does the number of shareholders.
    • In a closed-end mutual fund, the number of shareholders and the share structure is locked in from the beginning and the fund manager doesn't have to market the fund once all of the shareholders have been found.
    • If a shareholder wants to exit the fund, they don't deal with the fund manager but rather they sell their share on the secondary market to another investor.

• Learning Outcomes
  • After completing this module, you will be able to:

    • Explain what it means to take a short or long position with a company on the market.

    • Talk about what is involved with merger arbitrage.

    • Understand the importance of insider information when you are playing probabilities on the stock market.

    • Discuss how hedge fund managers use information to make decisions about investments.

• Lesson Summary
  • The key points from this module are:

    • A process is a program under execution from RAM and comprises of various sections: Executable instructions, stack, heap and State.

    • State is maintained by the system contains registers, list of open files, related process etc.

    • The user process cannot assess the kernel region.
    • System Calls are a set of functions that a OS supports, a user process can use a system call to access/ get information the Kernel. When a system call is invoked the processor shifts from user mode to privileged mode.
